ratings.comment: I took global economics with Paolo. Hardest core class I've taken at Stern. On the problem sets, we were expected to download data apply formulas (and extremely hard algebra and derivates) without any practice in class. There are too many lecture slides. There are too many formulas. Most of the lecture is not relevant and is just food for thought.
Paolo is not a good teacher, but he is a good talker.
Worst professor ever. I came to office hours only to find that his office was locked and he was chilling in the lounge.
Every class material being in the files tab in Canvas is certainly indicative of taking this with Paolo. Sure, it'll get the job done, but I know there was better way to have done it.

ECON 302 was not to me especially difficult in terms of content, but taking it with Martellini could certainly give one that impression. Class averages on the 3 tests only cracked 60% once (at 60.4), which led to a very generous curve at the end (75 for an A). This was likely due to a few factors, mainly boring lectures and bad study materials.

I really enjoyed Paolo's class. The way the class is structured can be frustrating because you're only graded on 3 midterms and 4 problem sets, but the lowest midterm and problem set is dropped. The class is challenging, but Paolo is very fair with his grade thresholds. In my opinion, you get out exactly what you put in.

Clearly knowledgeable about economics but the class is awful. Next to no study materials provided outside of the slides, which are almost no help. Lectures are fast, confusing, and make easy topics seem much harder than they actually are. Expect to learn the entire class off of YouTube if you take it with him.

I have to cut Paolo some slack since this was his first time teaching, but the lectures were very boring and monotonous, there were only 3 homework assignments (which were graded on a 30 point scale for 30 plus questions!) and the grading on the exams/homework was not the best.

Martinelli has wisdom, but this wisdom does not translate at all towards teaching. Pretty sure if I spent 10 minutes googling the material presented in class I would have gotten more out of the class than his lectures. Also if you do not perform well on a single exam do not expect to get your grade up at all.
My last post got removed because it was too rude I guess. I would recommend avoiding this professor at all costs. He ended up making the subject more confusing.

Paolo doesn't know how to teach students, even though he might be very knowledgeable about economics. Lectures are extremely confusing and convoluted, and they don't translate well to the exams which make up 80 percent of your grade. The TA's give hardly any partial credit on the exams which make or break your grade. Avoid Paolo as a teacher!

Professor Martellini is very knowledgeable about the content, and offers examples of how concepts apply to the real world. The class is structured well, with many helpful materials posted on canvas. The grading is heavily based on exams, with the lowest of the three scores dropped. Attending discussion and office hours will be benefit you greatly.
Very good professor. He will modify the teaching pace based on students' feedback. Also, the discussion is helpful

Lectures are the most confusing. Discussion section is not helpful at all. Lecture content translates very poorly to exams. Grade is based off two midterms and two homework assignments (drops lowest 1/3 for each). Homework is graded very harshly and so are exams. Would not recommend taking this class with him.
Probably the worst lecturer I have ever had. I have literally no idea what is going on or if I will pass. I miss Gwen
He doesnt know how to teach students. His lectures make literally no sense and theres no textbook. At any moment in class, if you look around everyone is equally as confused.
